evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 as documented in the hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes have been ruled out based on evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t2_interim data.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including timing, crew roles, and operational context as per hist_baseline_t2_interim.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 as documented in the hist_baseline_t2_interim dataset.

assumptions: The lack of warnings from wingman and headset operator indicates a communication breakdown rather than procedural deviation alone.
The trainee and instructor roles and interactions reflect crew coordination dynamics relevant to the claim.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew with no missed warnings or misunderstandings.
If mechanical or environmental factors were proven to be the primary cause rather than communication failure.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

He suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 directly document communication and coordination issues among crew during the pushback, including insufficient signaling and lack of warnings, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting whether procedural deviations or environmental factors contributed more significantly to the event.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including timing, crew roles, and operational context as per hist_baseline_t2_interim.

assumptions: The described communication and crew roles in the evidence reflect the key features relevant to the incident.
No mechanical faults or environmental deficiencies were primary contributors based on available evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural deviation without communication issues, or mechanical faults causing the event, the conclusion would change.
If environmental or marking deficiencies were shown to be primary causes, the communication breakdown alignment would be weaker.

However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 and H9 directly support that the procedural deviation relates to availability and adequacy of updated pushback procedure documentation and training to ground crew, as the trainee was aware of TRP but the visual stop signal was insufficient and no warnings were given, indicating procedural issues rather than environmental or marking deficiencies.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in whether the visual signals and training fully represent updated procedural documentation availability; no direct document evidence provided.

node.statement: Marking information (e.g., signage, runway markings) was present and accessible to the flight crew

defeaters: If evidence showed that markings were missing or not visible to the crew
If communication or visual signals were adequate and clearly perceived by the crew

defeaters: If clear procedural signals or communication warnings had been effectively given and observed, the mechanical/control failure claim might be weakened.
If evidence showed verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions confirming mechanical failure, it would strengthen the claim further.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

node.statement: Communication channels between pushback crew and flight deck were available and functional

No reported communication equipment failure or breakdown.
defeaters: If evidence showed communication equipment malfunction or lack of communication attempts, this would change the assessment.

The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

node.statement: Pushback crew was available at the scheduled time

assumptions: Presence of tug instructor and trainee driver in the tug implies availability at scheduled time
No evidence of crew absence or delay is present
defeaters: If evidence showed the crew was delayed or absent at the scheduled time

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H2, H3, and H9 directly indicate that the pushback crew (tug instructor and trainee driver) were present and active at the scheduled time, supporting availability. The discriminators favor procedural deviation over communication breakdown, environment, or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct timestamps confirming exact scheduled time presence; assumption that crew presence in narrative implies availability at scheduled time.

node.statement: Pushback equipment was operational and available

The absence of warnings from wingman or headset operator implies no equipment or communication failure.
defeaters: If evidence of equipment malfunction or fault traces were found, or bench checks indicated control issues, this would change the conclusion.
If communication failures or environmental factors were shown to have caused the incident, the assessment might differ.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The aircraft moved beyond the TRP (H4) despite operational equipment, indicating procedural deviation rather than mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement confirming equipment status; inference based on absence of fault reports and operational descriptions.
